Prospective MP Ben Flook has welcomed the news that Chesterfield has been awarded £20 million in funds to help regenerate it's town centre. This comes off the back of an initial £20 million of investment in Chesterfield in 2021, and £25 million for Staveley as part of the Government's Town Deals Fund.
The specific details on this fund will be announced in the coming months but, broadly, the £20 million is a ten-year ‘endowment style’ fund. It will now be down to Chesterfield Borough Council to put together a plan.
This is just the latest in a long line of examples where levelling up is really happening all across Chesterfield and Staveley:
- £25 million for Staveley regeneration through the Town Deal
- The new A&E at the Royal Hospital opened earlier this year
- The new Hartington unit for mental health at the Royal which is now under construction
- The first tranche of £20 million for Chesterfield town centre awarded a year or so ago
- The continuing regeneration of Chesterfield Canal
- The business case for the Chesterfield-Staveley by-pass
This is Levelling Up in action - by helping to create local, skilled jobs - as well as boosting tourism for our area.
Let Ben Flook know, below, how you would spend the new £20 million for Chesterfield to save our Town Centre.

As part of his campaign to support local apprenticeships, Ben Flook was delighted to visit Learning Curve's Hair and Beauty Chesterfield Academy this week, to meet Directors and students.
Ben enjoyed discussing the growth of courses at Chesterfield Academy with Learner Recruitment Officer, Helen Bradshaw, and plans to continuing the growth of Chesterfield Academy with local community groups.
Ben also received a treatment from second year beauty students - so pupils could put their learning into practice!
Upon visiting Chesterfield Academy, Ben said:
It was wonderful to speak to so many students and to Helen about their exciting plans for the future. Having been a teacher, supporting apprenticeships is vital to grow our skills base locally. I am delighted that the Government has invested £3.8 billion more into further education and skills - and is providing £1,000 payments to employers and providers when they take on apprentices. It is also good news that the Government has increased the apprentice national minimum wage, having accepted the Low Pay Commission's report in full.

I want to work with local people and businesses on Our 6 Point Plan to revive Chesterfield after decades of neglect by Labour MPs and the Labour Council.

Under Labour Councils and Labour MPs, Chesterfield's once great historic Market and Town Centre is dying.
Our Town Centre should be thriving. It's the gateway to the Peak District. There's tourist attractions all around us. And so much history to our Town.
But decades of Labour MPs and Labour Councils have watched our Town Centre decline.
But as your Prospective MP, I want to work with you to change that.
Like you, I want to make sure our local businesses and market traders have the support they need to thrive.
And ensure shoppers are encouraged to come to our Town Centre - not priced out through car parking like they are at the moment.
So I'm asking for your views - so we can work together to save Chesterfield Town Centre.
Let me know what action you want to see - so we can restore our great historic Market Town.
The Government have invested £40 million from the Levelling Up fund to help deliver projects - but we need to make sure the Labour Council spend it wisely.
Once I have all the surveys back, I’ll study the results with my team to get action on our shared priorities.
Thank you for helping to restore Chesterfield Town Centre.
Ben Flook
Prospective Conservative MP For Chesterfield

I'm Ben Flook, Prospective MP for Chesterfield. Since 2019, the Conservatives have invested £65 million in Chesterfield and Staveley; opened a new A&E at the Royal, a new community diagnostic centre and a new Mental Health Unit. We're getting the job done for Chesterfield.

As part of his campaign to Save Chesterfield Town Centre, Ben Flook has launched his campaign for 2 hours free parking to Save Chesterfield Town Centre.
At present, free parking is only available at restricted times. Local businesses have told Ben Flook that this doesn't help their businesses - as we instead need to attract people during peak hours.
Working with local market traders and business owners, Ben wants to bring in more people to our Town Centre - so we can help local businesses and create local jobs.
Speaking about his campaign, Ben said:
As part of my campaign to Save Chesterfield Town Centre, I want to bring 2 hours free parking to Chesterfield - to make visiting our Town more affordable for local people. That way, we can help local businesses.
